rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 13   Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 17   Value: 8
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 5    Value: 18
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 25   Value: 20
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 8    Value: 39
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
I hold:

- 13 Wheat (6) – 78 points  
- 17 Wood (8) – 136 points  
- 5 Sheep (18) – 90 points  
- 25 Brick (20) – 500 points  
- 8 Ore (39) – 312 points  

Total ≈ 1 116 points.

Sheep are the scarcest good on my side but also the one with the highest **marginal value** to me at the moment.  
Ore has the single-highest point value, so I’d like to hold on to most of it unless I can extract an absolute premium.

Bricks are abundant on my side; 25 Bricks are worth 500, but diminishing returns set in when you already have this many.

Immediate trade idea: convert surplus Brick into **extra Ore or Sheep**.  
A 4-to-1 or 3-to-2 rate seems fair given the numbers above.

I’ll start a conversation to gauge Player 1’s attitude.

[Turn 1]  
Hello! I have a lot of Brick to move. Would you be interested in any trades where you send Ore/Sheep in exchange?

rounds.response:
Analyzing the current state:  
- My total value is 13·6＋17·8＋5·18＋25·20＋8·39 = 78＋136＋90＋500＋312 = 1 116.  
- Prices on the “market”: Wheat 6, Wood 8, Sheep 18, Brick 20, Ore 39.  
- The prior offer (5 Brick + 3 Wheat → 2 Ore + 1 Sheep) was 100 + 18 = 118 given, 78 + 18 = 96 received—clearly winning 22 net for me but was rejected.  
To continue trying to exploit the big gap between Brick (20) and Ore (39) and further improve value, I will downgrade excess Brick and Wheat into the scarce & high-value Ore.

[Offer: 4 Brick, 2 Wheat -> 3 Ore, 1 Wood]

rounds.response:
My current resource totals:

- Wheat: 13 @ 6 → 78 points
- Wood: 17 @ 8 → 136 points
- Sheep: 5 @ 18 → 90 points
- Brick: 25 @ 20 → 500 points
- Ore: 8 @ 39 → 312 points
Total current value = 1,116 points

Key:  
Brick is my most abundant and lowest-value-per-unit good; Ore is my scarcest and highest-value-per-unit good. 

Look back at rejected offers:  
1st offer I asked for (2 Ore, 1 Sheep) giving up 5 Brick & 3 Wheat → they said no.  
2nd offer I asked for (3 Ore, 1 Wood) giving up 4 Brick & 2 Wheat → they said no.

Their side gave no counter-proposal; they simply denied. Therefore I need to sweeten the deal (or target a different resource mix) if I want Ore/Sheep. From my seen offers, Wood is clearly in excess on my side (they’d gain Wood each time) and Ore/Sheep are in short sum on my side. Since they also have lots of Brick (value 20) and may value Ore more highly (value 39) than I do, I should offer more Brick for smaller Ore bundles.

I’ll make a more favorable offer: give 5 Brick (100 points) and 2 Wheat (12 points) for only 1 Ore (39 points) + 1 Sheep (18 points).  
My net gain: +40 points (Ore + Sheep = 57 received vs 112 given).  
Them: 112 points received vs 57 given – should be attractive.

[Offer: 5 Brick, 2 Wheat -> 1 Ore, 1 Sheep]

rounds.response:
To maximize my expected value (EV) in the remaining turns, I need to (1) find trades that are +EV for me, (2) estimate which of those I can persuade Player 1 to accept, and (3) keep negotiating bandwidth open until the last possible moment.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Discounted surplus-check (EV units)

My current stock worth:  
13×6 + 17×8 + 5×18 + 25×20 + 8×39 = 1328

The items I am *short* of (high value/kg) are Ore (39) and Sheep (18), so they must be **received** in any offer I’m willing to accept.  Conversely, Brick is abundant (25 available, 20 value), so it is the natural currency I should spend.

I’ll now iterate only on offers where πMyGain > 0:

1. Ore for Brick costs π = 39 : 20  
   Breakeven ratio 1.95 Ore per Brick. So any trade where I **give ≤1 Brick per 1 Ore** is profitable.

2. Sheep for Brick costs π = 18 : 20 simply flips around. Since Brick is cheaper than Sheep, I’m fine giving 1 Brick for 1 Sheep, too.

This leads to two small, sharply +EV templates:

A. [Offer: 1 Brick -> 1 Ore]   πMyGain = 39-20 = +19  
B. [Offer: 1 Brick -> 1 Sheep]  πMyGain = 18-20 = –2   ⇒ discard

Only A is strictly positive for me.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Opponent’s Likely Acceptance Curve

No offer has been accepted so far, including those with more generous Brick giveaways (e.g. 5 Brick for 2 Ore earlier).  That suggests Player 1 is either Brick-rich or risk-averse. I should therefore **shrink** the ask in A slightly, bang-for-buck permitting, even though it reduces my EV: I’ll trade 2 Brick → 1 Ore. Net π = +17, still good.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Negotiation Plan

Turn 6 (now): send one small-stake offer to probe Player 1’s reserve again.  
Turns 7–10: escalate toward “1 Brick : 1 Ore” or 2-modifier splits once Player 1 shows appetite.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Action for Turn 6

[Offer: 2 Brick -> 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
I should recalculate the value I currently have and see where the biggest gaps are.  
Own totals (value = quantity × price):

- Wheat: 13×6  = 78  
- Wood : 17×8  = 136  
- Sheep: 5 ×18 = 90  
- Brick: 25×20 = 500  
- Ore  : 8 ×39 = 312  

Total value = 1116

Ore is my scarcest yet most valuable resource; I would still like to turn some surplus Brick into Ore.  
To keep it very simple I’ll again propose the smallest possible swap:

[Offer: 1 Brick -> 1 Ore]

0.reason: Same change in inventory value for all players. Draw.

1.reason: Same change in inventory value for all players. Draw.
